builtinAssetGallery.galleryTip: This is a free, built-in gallery of various textures and sounds. All the assets are CC0 or WTFPL, or are released under special terms for use in ct.js. In any way, you can use these assets however you like, in commercial and other projects.
builtinAssetGallery.cannotImportExplanation: The name that this asset would take is taken by some other asset. You may need to rename existing assets; or maybe you've already imported this asset?
builtinAssetGallery.cannotImportNameOccupied: Cannot import $1 as such name is already occupied.
builtinAssetGallery.visitSource: Open the store page of this asset pack
builtinAssetGallery.tipAuthor: Tip the author for their hard work :D

curveEditor.curveLineHint: Click the curve to add a point
curveEditor.dragPointHint: Drag to move the point, right-click to delete it

exportPanel.windowsCrossBuildWarning: To build for Windows from Linux/MacOS, you need Wine installed in your system. Install instructions are all different for various platforms, so you better google it yourself :)
exportPanel.cannotBuildForMacOnWin: Unfortunately, Windows can only produce broken Mac packages. Try using a Linux machine; for example, in a virtual one. It is 100% free!
exportPanel.projectTitleRequired: You must add a title to your project in the Project tab ‚Üí Authoring ‚Üí Name.
exportPanel.appIdRequired: You must set a unique appId in the Project tab ‚Üí Authoring ‚Üí App ID to distribute this app.
exportPanel.noAndroidSdkFound: No Android SDK was found (ANDROID_SDK_ROOT environment variable is not set). You can get Android SDK by installing Android Studio:
exportPanel.envVarNotice: You may still need to set this environment variable manually and restart your device.
exportPanel.requiresInternetNotice: This operation requires Internet connection to setup each project.
exportPanel.noJdkFound: No JDK 11 was found (JAVA_HOME environment variable is not set or doesn't point to JDK 11). You can get JDK 11 here:
exportPanel.firstRunNotice: The first run for each platform will be slow as ct.js will download and save additional libraries needed for packing. It will take some time, but next times will be almost instant.

exporterError.exporterErrorHeader: An error occured while exporting your project

clueSolutions.syntax: This is a syntax error in your code. Go to the asset and fix it ‚Äî the code editor will highlight the problematic place.
clueSolutions.eventConfiguration: One of the events is misconfigured, having empty fields. Go to the asset and edit its event's parameters.
clueSolutions.emptySound: One of your sounds does not have any sound files attached. Import a sound file to it or remove this empty sound.
clueSolutions.emptyEmitter: One of your particle systems is missing a texture in its emitter. You will need to either set a texture to it or remove the emitter.
clueSolutions.windowsFileLock: This is a Windows-specific problem with a locked file. Make sure you've closed all external browsers that launched the game, then try exporting again. If it doesn't help, restart ct.js.

intro.loading: Please wait: kittens are gathering speed of light!

newProject.selectProjectFolder: Select a folder in which to store your project

recovery.message:
Recovery

ct.js has found a recovery file. Possibly, your project was not saved correctly or ct.js was shut down in case of some emergency. Here is when these files were lastly modified:

Your chosen file: {0} {1}
Recovery file: {2} {3}

What file should ct.js open?

intro.loadingProjectError: Cannot open this project because of the following error:
intro.cloneProject: Clone this project into a new location
intro.templatesInfo: You can kickstart your game development by using one of these templates. They contain placeholder graphics only but have working mechanics. Selecting a project will open a save directory selector for your new project.
intro.unableToWriteToFolders: Ct.js could not find an appropriate place for projects! Make sure you store ct.js app inside a folder you have access to write to.

onboarding.hoorayHeader: Wow! You've just created a project!
onboarding.openSpaceShooterTutorial: Learn how to make a space shooter
onboarding.openPlatformerTutorial: Learn how to make a platformer
onboarding.openJettyCatTutorial: Learn how to make a Jetty Cat
onboarding.doNothing: Skip this screen and make a great game!
onboarding.showOnboardingCheckbox: Show this screen when creating a new project

languageSelector.chooseLanguageExplanation: This is the language you will write events with to describe your gameplay logic. Previously, all the projects used JavaScript+TypeScript. Note that you can only convert CoffeeScript projects to JavaScript, but not the other way around, so choose carefully!
languageSelector.coffeeScriptDescription: A good language for beginners with a simple syntax. Pick this language if you don't have prior experience with programming with code, or if you love Python.
languageSelector.jsTsDescription: The language of the web. Its syntax is more complex but it has in-editor error highlighting and code suggestions. Choose it if you worked with JS, C# or Java code before.

actions.heading: Actions and input methods
actions.methodModuleMissing: The required module for this method is missing
actions.noActionsYet: Actions allow developers to listen to numerous input methods at once and dynamically change them, all with one uniform API. Read more by clicking on the docs icon above.
actions.importErrorMissingModules: Cannot import action preset as your ct.js installation lacks following modules: $1.
actions.importErrorNotCtJsPreset: This file doesn't look like ct.js' actions preset.

authoring.heading: Authoring
authoring.author: Developer:
authoring.title: Name:
authoring.appIdExplanation: This is mainly used in mobile builds. It is a unique string that identifies your game. It usually follows the format zone.developer.projectName, and, say, rocks.ctjs.catsteroids is a good example for that.

branding.heading: Branding
branding.accentNotice: Sets the color of the preloader, as well as of some other places if used as a mobile app.
branding.iconNotice: It should be a square, one-frame texture that is at least 256x256px large.
branding.splashScreenNotice: This image will be used in mobile builds. It should be at least 1920x1920px large, and will be resized and cropped for portrait and landscape screen orientation, so make sure everything important is in the center square.
branding.forceSmoothIcons: Use smooth icons regardless of rendering settings
branding.forceSmoothSplashScreen: Use smooth splash screen images regardless of rendering settings
branding.hideLoadingLogo: Hide "Made with ct.js" graphics on the loading screen

content.heading: Content type editor
content.unnamedContentTypeHint: This content type is unnamed. It will not be usable in-game unless you add the name.
content.typeNameHint: The name of your content type as it will be used in code. Examples: GearItems, EnemySkills, Cities.
content.typeReadableNameHint: The readable name of your content type, which is shown here and in content editors.
content.fieldNameHint: The name of the field as it will be used in code. For example: power, hp, spawnType.
content.fieldReadableNameHint: The readable version of the name, which is used in the content editor.
content.confirmDeletionMessage: Are you sure you want to delete this content type? It is irreversible and will also delete all the entries of this content type.

rendering.heading: Render Options
rendering.highDensity: Support high pixel density (e.g. on retina screens)
rendering.usePixiLegacy: Add a legacy, canvas-based renderer to support older browsers and graphics cards (adds ~20kb up to your game)
rendering.pixelatedRender: Disable image smoothing here and in exported project (preserve crisp pixels)

scripts.heading: Custom scripts
scripts.newScriptComment: Use scripts to define frequent functions and import small libraries

export.heading: Export settings
export.functionWrap: Wrap all the code in a function. (Makes debugging harder, but isolates the game's code from outer context. Do not enable while developing the game.)
export.obfuscateWarning: This option will make your code run 15-80% slower, but will make your code extremely hard to revert back to the original.
export.codeModifierAndWrapNote: Note that these settings only work for exported projects (Export for web and Export for desktop commands) as they noticeably slow packaging and make debugging harder. You can force them, though, in the Main menu ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Force production tasks for debug exports.

modules.author: Author of this catmod
modules.previewTooltip: This module has not yet been released and is for preview purposes.
modules.deprecatedTooltip: This module is deprecated and will be removed in a future version.

textureGenerator.name: Texture's name:
textureGenerator.label: Label:
textureGenerator.scalingAtX4: Scaling by x4 for a small texture
textureGenerator.generationSuccessMessage: Successfully added $1 texture to your project.

soundRecorder.cannotRecordSound: Cannot start recorder: check your audio configuration and the recording device.
soundRecorder.troubleshootingWindows: On Windows, also go to Settings -> Privacy -> Microphone and check that apps are allowed to access your microphone.

particleEmitters.minimumSizeHint: Setting it to lower values will randomize the size of each particle. The lower the values, the stronger the effect.
particleEmitters.minimumSpeedHint: Setting it to lower values will randomize the speed of each particle; the lower the value, the slower the particle may be.
particleEmitters.gravityNotice: Note that if it differs from (0;0), velocity interpolation will be disabled, meaning that only the first node of the velocity graph will have the effect.
particleEmitters.prewarmDelayNotice: Negative values will prepare the particles of the emitter before showing it, which is useful for long effects like dust particles or mist that should already be visible on room start; positive values will delay the simulation.
particleEmitters.alreadyHasAnImportingTexture: You already have a texture named $1. Either delete it or rename it; though you must be importing the same texture you've added before :)

patreon.aboutPatrons: Patrons are people who show their support to ComigoGames at Boosty, in form of recurring donations, similarly to subscriptions on Patreon.
patreon.thankAllPatrons: Thanks to all ComigoGames patrons, current and former ones, as your support keeps Comigo moving forward and making even better apps! :)
patreon.noSponsorsYet: There're no sponsors yet. You can be the first!
patreon.sponsorsDescription: Sponsors are displayed as such on ct.js site and other pages, like on ct.js game jams.
patreon.businessCatsDescription: Business cats get access to a special support channel on Discord server and receive support for ct.js and gamedev as a whole, too.
patreon.catsDescription: Cats are people that want to support ct.js with more than just "thanks". They get listed in ct.js (here!) and everywhere CoMiGo remembers to add them.
aboutFillers: has yet to become a star üí´

writableFolderPrompt.headerSelectFolderForData: Select a folder for ct.js data
writableFolderPrompt.paragraphCouldNotPickDirectory: Oh noes! Ct.js could not find a folder for your projects, package builds, and for debugging. Ct.js usually finds one automatically, but this time all the folders it was looking for are read-only!
writableFolderPrompt.paragraphDirectoryDirections: This can be fixed, though. Click the button below and select a folder at which to store data. If you are unsure, create a "ct.js" directory in your Documents folder.

writableFolderSelector.folderDoesNotExist: It seems that this folder does not exist‚Ä¶ How did you do that?
writableFolderSelector.notADirectory: This doesn't seem to be a directory! How did you do that?
writableFolderSelector.folderNotWritable: You don't have access to write to this folder. Pick another one.
writableFolderSelector.complete: Folder was set, all is good ‚úÖ

project.heading: Project
project.confirmationConvertToJs: This will automatically convert ALL the events in the project to JavaScript. This action is irreversible. (Though it will rollback if it finds an error in your scripts.) Are you sure you want to convert this CoffeeScript project to JavaScript?

appView.launchHotkeys: (F5; Alt+F5 to run in your default browser)

tour.aboutTour: Welcome to ct.js! This little tour will show you the main controls in this editor, so you know how to configure ct.js and create new assets.
tour.helpPanel: First of all, note this sneaky button. It is very important for learning ct.js!
tour.helpPanelTabs:
This panel stores all the official docs and tutorials for ct.js and its modules, and also has two notepads for your records.

Global notepad is shared between projects and is saved on your device. Project's notepad is stored inside your project.
tour.projectResources: Now, every project has assets of several types. Every asset type belongs to its own tab. Let's check out the most important tabs.
tour.tabTextures: Textures are images that can be used for your interactive objects (which are called Copies), backgrounds, and special effects. Textures don't do anything on their own but are definitely a needed asset type.
tour.tabTexturesImport: You can import textures from your file system‚Ä¶
tour.tabTexturesGallery: ‚Ä¶or import ready-made textures from the built-in library.
tour.tabTexturesClipboard: This button pastes copied images from clipboard. It is quite handy while working with image editors!
tour.tabTexturesPlaceholders: You can also generate simple placeholder graphics with this tool.
tour.tabTemplates: Templates are used to create copies ‚Äî interactive objects that you place in your levels. Any interactive object in ct.js is created from one of your templates. They use your textures, and you define gameplay logic by creating events in them. Once you've created a template, you can run its own in-deep tour in the template editor.
tour.tabRooms: Another most important tab is for rooms. Rooms can also be called as levels or scenes in which you place your copies. Rooms can also have their own events and backgrounds.
tour.tabSounds: Sounds, I guess, is the most obvious tab.
tour.tabSoundsImport: You can create new sounds with this button‚Ä¶
tour.tabSoundsGallery: ‚Ä¶import them from the built-in sound library‚Ä¶
tour.tabSoundsRecord: ‚Ä¶or even record them with your microphone!
tour.tabInterlude: There are also two tabs for more advanced assets.
tour.tabUI: UI tab manages fonts and text styles. Bundling your fonts with the game is important for it to look consistently across devices. Text styles have a visual editor for making style presets. They also produce code for creation of such labels in-game.
tour.tabFX: The FX tab has an editor for particle systems ‚Äî special graphical effects for explosions, magic, smoke, rain, all this kind of stuff.
tour.tabProject: That's it for the assets! But besides these, your project also has a bunch of settings for rendering, branding, packaging and whatnot.
tour.tabProjectModules: Ct.js is modular, and your projects may need additional modules that can be installed here.
tour.tabProjectModuleDocs: All the docs for enabled modules can be found here.
tour.tabMainMenu: Ct.js itself has plenty of options, which are stored in its main menu.
tour.tabMainMenuSettings: You can change the language and how ct.js looks in the Settings section.
tour.tabMainMenuMeta: If you'll need help later, you will be able to find all the official hubs in the Meta panel.
tour.helpPanelReminder: Also don't forget about the built-in docs! We do recommend completing official tutorials before starting your own projects.

roomBackgrounds.notBackgroundTextureWarning: This texture is not marked as a background. It will have gaps when exported.

roomTiles.addTileLayerFirst: Firstly add a tile layer in the left panel!

roomView.name: Name:
roomView.followCodeHint: Learn how to further tweak this feature with code
roomView.hotkeysNotice: Ctrl = Delete, Alt = No grid, Shift = Multiple

copyCustomProperties.nameOccupied: This property is used by ct.js! You should come up with a different name.

textureView.axisExplanation: Defines which place is counted as (0;0) position of a copy and affects how it positions itself relative to a grid, and around which point it rotates.
textureView.isometrify: Isometrify: Move the axis to the middle bottom point, fill the whole sprite with a collision mask
textureView.name: Name:
textureView.corrupted: File is corrupted or missing! Closing now.
textureView.blankTextureNotice: Exports the image as a transparent rectangle, thus being invisible in-game. Useful for making placeholders for ct.js editor while keeping bundle size slim.
textureView.paddingNotice: This affects how a texture is exported: it adds duplicate pixels on edges and prevents bleeding artifacts on tiled and scaled textures. The default value is usually enough, but, if you shrink textures strongly, the bleeding may re-appear. Increment this value if this texture has artifacts while in-game.
textureView.previewAnimationNotice: This is a preview. Use this.animationSpeed property to change it for real copies.

charsets.punctuation: Digits and punctuation (you usually do need this)

fontView.customCharsetHint: Type all the letters you want to include, both in upper and lower case.

licensePanel.whoOwnsGamesQ: Who owns games created in ct.js?
licensePanel.whoOwnsGamesA: You and only you. Ct.js does not own anything you create in any way.
licensePanel.sellingGamesQ: Can I sell games made in ct.js?
licensePanel.sellingGamesA: Yes, you can sell your games and other projects, gather donations, and use your games in any other commercial applications.
licensePanel.possibleFeesQ: Do I need to pay for ct.js? Will ct.js become paid someday?
licensePanel.possibleFeesA: No, ct.js is free and will always be so. It doesn't have any hidden fees like Unity or Unreal Engine that require you paying after you earn a specific amount of money. Ct.js is open-source, and even if there will be any paid versions, the product you have now will always be accessible free of charge. You can send a donation or become a patron, though! It will help us pay bills and make ct.js better!
licensePanel.useInStudioQ: Can I use ct.js in a studio or schools?
licensePanel.useInStudioA: Sure, why not? Ct.js is open for personal, commercial, educational use, and whatnot. Just don't break the law, ok?
licensePanel.attributionQ: Do I need to attribute ct.js or its developers? Can I disable its logo on the loading screen?
licensePanel.attributionA: You can disable the ct.js logo, as the code of your game already has the necessary attributions.
licensePanel.attributionAAssets: Some of the examples and demos may contain material that needs attribution, but that is already included in them.

scriptables.removeEventConfirm: Are you sure you want to remove this event? This can't be undone!
scriptables.createEventHint: Create your first event in the left column, and define your logic here

coreEventsDescriptions.OnCreate: Triggers when your copy is created.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnRoomStart: Triggers when this room is created, either by switching to it or by adding it as a layer.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnStep: Happens at the beginning of every frame.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnDraw: Happens at the end of every frame. Good for animation updates.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnDestroy: Happens between "frame start" and "frame end" when this copy gets destroyed.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnRoomEnd: Triggers when you switch to another room, or when this room is removed after it was added as a layer.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnActionPress: Happens when an action's input becomes active ‚Äî by pressing, clicking, flicking a joystick, etc.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnActionRelease: Happens when an action's input becomes inactive ‚Äî by releasing buttons, resting joysticks, etc.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnActionDown: Runs every frame if an action's input is active.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnAnimationLoop: Fires every time an animation restarts.
coreEventsDescriptions.OnAnimationComplete: Fires once a non-looping animation finishes.
coreEventsDescriptions.Timer: Set the duration for this timer in seconds with this.timer$1 = 3;
